body: Unit test passed locally.

Thank you, @ijuma . 
I updated the PR according to your comments.
Thanks for the patch! And the failures have been fixed in a previous commit. LGTM except a minor comment about unit test cleaning.
@guozhangwang Yes, it passed on first try this time :) I moved the common properties out of the test methods.
Thanks @guozhangwang
@guozhangwang have a look when you can, thanks!

Jenkins failures are not related. There is a JIRA created for it already.

LGTM and merged to trunk.
Ping @apovzner @norwood @enothereska for reviews.
@ewencp Could you take a look?
LGTM! Merged to trunk.
LGTM

@bbejeck @norwood The problem with using a given logger is that the logging level is universal, and hence users either 1) use a separate logger which is not used anywhere else, and set in log4j.properties the logging level for this specific logger, or 2) use a shared logger and tolerate it outputs other entries with the same logging level. Hence I'd prefer keep the current APIs and add the log4j support for print when we see common usage that requires it.
@bbejeck As for the rebasing option, you can either rebase and squash the commits, or just create a new PR and close this one. Either is fine.
Could we have some unit tests validating the internal source topics and changelog topics configs, as well as their number of partitions?
Thanks @ijuma and @guozhangwang , will address and currently thinking of unit tests too.
@guozhangwang Thanks, I'll do the latter.

@guozhangwang All the changes look sensible. The only question I have is why some checks ignore `null` keys and others throw an exception. It seems inconsistent even where they seem similar, e.g. `KStreamKStreamJoin` vs `KStreamKTableLeftJoin`. Shouldn't it always be an error to have a `null` key for these cases or always just filter them out so the behavior is predictable?

@ewencp For KStream, it is possible the key is null and that for operations depending on key like joins and aggregates, we will just ignore that key; for KTable, the key should not be null and if that happens, we throw exceptions;

As for KStreamKStreamJoin, it is actually the last operator of the translated sub-graph, where null keyed record should already been filtered in the previous operator, like KStreamWindowed, and hence it is not expected to see null key any more in that operator.
Thanks for the PR, can you please edit the PR title to be more descriptive? it becomes the commit title once the PR is merged.
Absolutely sorry about that. Will the description in the JIRA I filed suffice?
I think the use of `||` is correct.

That's fair, I must have interpreted this incorrectly. Should the error message reflect this behavior then? 

In the event the first operand is evaluated correctly the second will not be evaluated.
@rnpridgeon not a problem. Thanks for the contribution. If you find it is an issue, feel free to re-open the pr with some more details.

@rnpridgeon I think the code and message is accurate as is. Perhaps the error message could be made more clear if you like. Something like 2 separate if checks so each statement is about a singe config or including the found/invalid values in the log message might help. Its up to you if you think that is valuable.
@granthenke Yeah, you are correct. In my mind I wanted the happy path to be the result of a true statement as opposed to a false. Live and learn
LGTM

Note for reviewers: I've added a few test cases which are probably risks for future transient failures. Unfortunately it's difficult to test this without using system time since the coordinator depends on the purgatory implementation which doesn't work with MockTime. Any ideas to fix this would be appreciated.
@guozhangwang Ok, makes sense and thanks for educating me! LGTM

Thanks, we're rolling this fix out across production at the moment. Each server connects to enough brokers and we have many many brokers that this message was the top 'error' message across all our applications.
@bondj If this is a useful change, then you may consider submitting a PR with trunk as the target. That way, you will not have to patch again when you upgrade.

@ijuma Looking at the code, I think the problem is specific to 0.8 client talking 0.9 server.  Hopefully, once we've upgraded our clients to 0.9 (which will take a while), we won't need the patch anymore.
@bondj OK, great.

@hachikuji Oops, now that I actually read your follow up note, I realize one of my comments was already addressed.
1. One concern is infinite forwarding loops -- can you get a case where a stale worker A forwards to worker B which it thinks is leader, worker B can also be stale, etc.? I guess in order for this to actually loop you'd probably need some ridiculous number of nodes with stale leadership info and having gone stale at different times?
2. Has the KIP been updated? I only see a case for 409 if there is an existing restart in progress. Arguably this is a little weird anywhere except for when you need to forward (you can always just use simple locking and restart multiple times to satisfy the request).

Generally the patch looks good; the 202 status codes are now out of date, but we knew some stuff  would need updating after KIP refinements. However, shouldn't need huge changes to get this ready for commit.

@apovzner @granders Minor follow up from the previous patch for verifiable producer. I've kicked off tests here: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/409 and they look like they should finish up cleanly. The failed tests were for MM and were due to the fact that the MM test creates the verifiable producer immediately in the `__init__` method, before the security config is set on Kafka. This just makes the lookup dynamic so we don't have to wait to instantiate the service.

We may want to follow this approach more generally too -- this gets rid of the annoying pattern of having to instantiate all services in the test itself as long as the services like ZK and Kafka properly handle setting the security protocol after instantiation. I think we want this anyway because any test where we'd want to shutdown, modify settings, and start up with new security configs would require this as well.
@gwenshap, @guozhangwang, @junrao If any of you can look, this needs another committer to review as well. Very trivial patch.
@ewencp Makes sense - this looks good to me
LGTM.
Thanks @ewencp !
@apovzner Could you check it this fixed your issue?
Closing the PR due to merging/rebase issues.  Will re-open a new PR related to JIRA KAFKA-3338

Comments addressed from closed PR #1187 
@guozhangwang - 
- Changed print and writeAsText method return signature to void 
- Flush System.out on close, 
- Changed IllegalStateException to TopologyBuilderException, 
- Updated JavaDoc stating need to override toString,

@norwood 
- Renamed KStreamPrinter to KeyValuePrinter
- Updated the printing of null keys to 'null' to match ConsoleConsumer

OK, so the test passed 67 times and then it failed with what I think is an unrelated failure:

[INFO:2016-04-09 03:35:02,127]: SerialTestRunner: Summary: There aren't enough available nodes to satisfy the resource request. Total cluster size: 0, Requested: 1, Already allocated: 0, Available: 0. Make sure your cluster has enough nodes to run your test or service(s). Currently registered services: [<ZookeeperService: num_nodes: 1, nodes: []>]
I see no errors in test results, but build is failed. Any issue on my side?
@gwenshap mind taking a look. Thanks!
@bbejeck I have modified the behavior of `MockProcessorContext` in https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1204, would that help your unit tests?
LGTM. One comment about time dependency.
@bbejeck That is fine. If yours gets merged earlier I will just rebase mine :)
LGTM. Merged to trunk. Thanks @bbejeck !
looks good to me too

I see that the first punctuate() is called right away on startup, not after the scheduled interval. Is this an intended behavior.

Otherwise, the code works. I see only very rarely that punctuate() is called about 10 times at the same time. The pattern is normally: first punctuate() is called, and then the next time punctuate() is called, it is called one after another several times. After that, one punctuate() is called every 'interval'. It is not a consistent behavior.

I got it now. If the punctuate() is triggered based on event time, then the behavior I describe above makes sense. 

If the intended behavior is to call punctuate() in the beginning first, not after 'interval', then LGTM.
looks good to me
Merged to trunk.

Thanks for the PR @dpkp. I haven't looked in detail, but the idea is appealing. Let's see what committers think. In order to ensure that this works as expected, we would want to expand our system tests to cover LZ4 as well:

https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/tests/kafkatest/tests/core/upgrade_test.py#L65
https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/tests/kafkatest/tests/core/compatibility_test_new_broker_test.py#L52

By the way, there's another wrinkle. This change probably means that a new ApiVersion (see the class documentation for details) called KAFKA_0_10_0_IV1 needs to be introduced for people who have adopted trunk in production after KAFKA_0_10_0_IV0 was introduced (and before this PR).

However, it would make things a lot simpler (for clients and testing) if we didn't have to bump the version again (which would benefit people using trunk and LZ4). Let's see what @junrao thinks.
@gwenshap can you please review this?
LGTM. Merged to trunk. Thanks @stepio !
@guozhangwang have a look when you can. Thanks.
Thanks for the reviews. Merged to trunk.
@hachikuji Sorry for the late reply. I left some reply to the review comments. Will add unit tests as well.
LGTM
It seems this conflicts with KAFKA-3510. I'll do the rebase.
cc @junrao. Will you be able to help review this patch? Thanks!

Looks good overall.

Could we add explanations for those general exceptions for "when such exceptions can be thrown" like KafkaExceptions / StreamsExceptions / IllegalStateExceptions as the exception names themselves do not reveal too much hints. As an example in KafkaConsumer we tried to add as much information on that regards as possible to help developers.
@ijuma . Could you review this again please? :)
Thanks @guozhangwang

@junrao @gwenshap @guozhangwang @ewencp @ijuma 
This patch represents the current vote thread for the KIP-4 Metadata changes. Please feel free to review at your convenience.

I am not sure whether it is possible for send to block forever after the patch mentioned above. The call to `poll(future)` should return after the request timeout expires. @WarrenGreen If you have a case where you were able to reproduce this bug, it would be helpful to try it on trunk to see whether we still need this patch.
@hachikuji, I thought that test in the PR would verify that.

I don't think that would be sufficient since it uses a mock of `ConsumerNetworkClient`. After Rajini's patch, there is just one call to send() and one to poll(), so the behavior is controlled entirely by the mock's expectations.
LGTM!
Fair enough.
Merged to trunk.

Thanks for the PR.

Another approach is the one done in `BaseProducerSendTest.createProducer` where we keep track of instantiated producers and close them in `tearDown`. It would be nice to have a consistent way to handle closable resources. Thoughts?
LGTM, cc @gwenshap

@ijuma These tests leverage `BaseConsumerTest` and the `IntegrationTestHarness` that uses that pattern in most cases. This patch is closing the consumers that are not a part of that pattern and are specially instantiated in each test.
cc @gwenshap @ewencp
Thank you, @ijuma !
LGTM
huh. why is it even here?
LGTM. Thank you for contributing!
Thank YOU, @gwenshap ! :)
@gwenshap I forgot to remove that when I removed the dependency on Hadoop's MiniKdc.
@granthenke Yes, I realise that. The example I gave is for producers that are specially instantiated in each test and not via the usual harness way.
LGTM. We will consider adding integration tests for Kafka Streams as unit tests as a separate task.

@granthenke @ijuma @guozhangwang Sorry for the belated response, I just saw your comments. I will rebase the patch. The version check on this patch makes sense, but the returned unsupported version might will only work for the responses that have an error code field. With KIP-35 a well behaved client should not send unsupported API version to the broker. But from the broker's point of view, we probably still need to handle this in case there are some problematic clients. 

I will rebase this and update the PR. Thanks.

The latest commit replaces the request-response to configure SASL mechanisms with aSaslHandshakeRequest/SaslHandshakeResponse pair that conforms to the standard Kafka protocol, as discussed in the KIP-35/KIP-43 threads in the mailing list. The overall code structure for authentication/handshake has not been changed.
@ijuma @ewencp a kindly reminder

@granthenke This does seem to be cleaning up some of the unreliability of builds on Confluent's Jenkins when I test it against this branch (based only on a couple of builds which passed on the first try, compared to our ~10% pass rate normally).

Agree with @ijuma that it might be better to leverage existing code for making sure things are cleaned up (and avoids a ton of `try`/`finally` blocks, which we kind of get implicitly with `tearDown`). It looks like we could just `append` to `producers` and `consumers` and `IntegrationTestHarness` takes care of the rest?

@ijuma That actually sounds like something went wrong with getting the list of machines available in the cluster (or they shutdown or something). This is what you normally get if you don't have any nodes started, or if you just don't have enough nodes for the test if the numbers are larger. 67 passes is enough to convince me :)

LGTM
Review by @gwenshap if/when you have time.
@guozhangwang @ijuma: Thanks for the reviews. I've updated per the comments above and offline discussion.
LGTM. Merged to trunk. Thanks @hachikuji !
Review by @guozhangwang
